name: Kepler-85
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-85 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-85 is a star with 0.785 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.89 times its radius. It is located 2550.83 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-85 is known to have 4 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-85 d

Kepler-85 d was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.13 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 17.91 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-85.

The mass of Kepler-85 d is 1.49 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-85 d is 1.2 that of Earth. At less than 1.5 Earth masses, Kepler-85 d is a regular terrestrial planet, much like the terrestrial planets we find in our solar system, namely Mercury, Venus, Earth and Mars.

Kepler-85 e

Kepler-85 e was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.16 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 25.22 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-85.

The mass of Kepler-85 e is 1.70 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-85 e is 1.27 that of Earth. At 1.70 Earth masses, Kepler-85 e is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-85, which contains 4 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
